{{Infobox Wrestling event |name=Rey de Reyes (2002) |image=El Canek.jpg |caption=[[Canek (wrestler)|Canek]], won the 2002 Rey de Reyes tournament |promotion=[[Lucha Libre AAA World Wide|AAA]] |date=March 17, 2002<ref name="Rey2002">{{cite web | url = http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/rey.html#2002 | title = Asistencia Asesoria y Administracion Rey de Reyes Tournament| accessdate = February 19, 2009 | date= March 17, 2002| publisher= ProWrestlingHistory.com}}</ref> |venue= |city=[[Zapopan]], [[Jalisco]], [[Mexico]]<ref name="Rey2002"/> |attendance= |liveevent=Y |lastevent=[[Guerra de Titanes (2001)]] |nextevent=[[Triplemanía X]] |event=[[Rey de Reyes]] |lastevent2=[[Rey de Reyes (2001)]] |nextevent2=[[Rey de Reyes (2003)]] }} The '''Rey de Reyes 2002''' ([[Spanish language|Spanish]] for "King of Kings") was the sixth annual [[Rey de Reyes]] [[professional wrestling]] tournament and show, produced by the Mexican [[wrestling promotion]] [[Lucha Libre AAA World Wide|AAA]]. The event took place on March 17, 2002, in [[Zapopan]], [[Jalisco]], [[Mexico]]. The tournament consisted of a semi-final round of four four-man elimination matches and a final match with the winners of each of the semi-finals facing off in an elimination match until only one man remained. The final of the 2002 tournament pitted [[Canek (wrestler)|Canek]], [[Pirata Morgan]], [[Cibernético]] and [[Octagón]] against each other. The show featured two additional matches beyond the five tournament matches.
==Production== ===Background=== Starting in 1997 and every year since then the Mexican ''[[Lucha Libre]]'', or [[professional wrestling]], [[wrestling promotion|company]] [[Lucha Libre AAA World Wide|AAA]] has held a [[Rey de Reyes]] (Spanish for "King of Kings') show in the spring. The 1997 version was held in February,<ref name="Rey1997">{{cite web | url = http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/rey.html#1997 | title = Asistencia Asesoria y Administracion Rey de Reyes | accessdate = February 19, 2009 | date=February 21, 1997 | publisher= ProWrestlingHistory.com}}</ref> while all subsequent Rey de Reyes shows were held in March. As part of their annual Rey de Reyes event AAA holds the [[eponym]]ious 'ey de Reyes tournament to determine that specific year's ''Rey''.<ref name=YIR1997>{{cite news|title=1997 Especial!|work=Box y Lucha Magazine|pages=2–28|id=issue 2332|date=January 7, 1998|language=Spanish}}</ref> Most years the show hosts both the qualifying round and the final match, but on occasion the qualifying matches have been held prior to the event as part of AAA's weekly television shows.<ref name=Lucha2004>{{cite news|title=Número Especial - Lo mejor de la lucha libre mexicana durante el 2004|work=SuperLuchas|id=Issue 91|date=January 24, 2005|language=Spanish}}</ref> The traditional format consists of four preliminary rounds, each a [[Professional wrestling match types#Basic elimination matches|Four-man elimination match]] with each of the four winners face off in the tournament finals, again under elimination rules.<ref name="Rey1997"/> There have been years where AAA has employed a different format to determine a winner.<ref name=Lucha2004/> The winner of the Rey de Reyes tournament is given a large ornamental sword to symbolize their victory, but is normally not guaranteed any other rewards for winning the tournament, although some years becoming the Rey de Reyes has earned the winner a match for the [[AAA Mega Championship]]. From 1999 through 2009 AAA also held an annual ''[[AAA Reina de Reinas Championship|Reina de Reinas]]'' ("Queen of Queens") tournament, but later turned that into an actual championship that could be defended at any point during the year, abandoning the annual tournament concept.<ref name=Reinas1999>{{Cite book | author=Royal Duncan and Gary Will | title=Wrestling Title Histories | publisher=Archeus Communications |chapter= Mexico: AAA Reina de Reinas | page= 400 | year= 2000 | isbn=0-9698161-5-4}}</ref><ref name=Reinas12>{{cite news | author = SuperLuchas staff | title = Lo Mejor de la Lucha Libre Mexicana 2008 | work =SuperLuchas | id = issue 296 | date = January 6, 2008 | url=http://superluchas.net/?p=11145 | accessdate = July 11, 2009| language = Spanish}}</ref><ref name=Reinas13>{{cite web | url= http://superluchas.net/2009/09/26/aaa-heroes-inmortales-homenaje-a-antonio-pena-resultados-en-vivo-26-septiembre-2009-%C2%BFque-pasara-con-la-lucha-entre-charly-manson-y-chessman-%C2%BFquien-sera-el-luchador-sorpresa/ | title= AAA- Héroes Inmortales III- (Resultados en vivo 26 septiembre 2009) – Cibernético gana el Trofeo Antonio Peña – Electroshock sustituye a Charly Manson contra Chessman – El luchador sorpresa fue Konan Big | author= Marquina, Alva | date= September 26, 2009 | accessdate= September 27, 2009 | publisher= ''SuperLuchas'' Magazine| language=Spanish}}</ref> The 2002 show was the sixth Rey de Reyes show in the series.
===Storylines=== The Rey de Reyes show featured five [[Professional wrestling match types|professional wrestling matches]] with different wrestlers involved in pre-existing, scripted feuds, plots, and storylines. Wrestlers were portrayed as either [[Heel (professional wrestling)|heels]] (referred to as ''rudos'' in Mexico, those that portray the "bad guys") or [[Face (professional wrestling)|faces]] (''técnicos'' in Mexico, the "good guy" characters) as they followed a series of tension-building events, which culminated in a wrestling match or series of matches.

{{Infobox Convention | name = Rue Morgue Festival of Fear (Canadian National Horror Expo) | image = | caption = | status = Active | genre = Multi-genre | venue = Metro Toronto Convention Centre | location = Toronto, Ontario | country = Canada | first = 2004 | last = | organizer = Rue Morgue Magazine/Hobby Star Marketing Inc. joint | filing = Corporate | attendance = 91,000 in 2012 | website = http://www.fanexpocanada.com/ }}
[[Toronto]], Canada's '''Festival of Fear''' is an annual multigenre fan convention that runs as part of [[Fan Expo Canada]]. It was founded as the '''Canadian National Horror Expo''' in 2004 by ''[[Rue Morgue Magazine]]'' and Hobby Star Marketing Inc. It is traditionally a three-day event (Friday through Sunday) typically held the weekend before [[Labour Day]] during the summer in [[Toronto]], Canada, at the [[Metro Toronto Convention Centre]]. Since 2011 it has become a four-day-long event.
Originally showcasing novels, fantasy, film, television and related popular arts, the convention has expanded over the years to include a larger range of [[popular culture|pop culture]] elements, such as [[Horror and terror|horror]], [[anime]], [[manga]], [[animation]], [[toy]]s, [[collectible card game]]s, [[video game]]s and web entertainment. The convention is the largest of its kind in Canada and among the largest in world, filling the entire south building of the [[Metro Toronto Convention Centre]] with over 91,000 attendees in 2012.
Along with panels, seminars, and workshops with industry professionals, there are previews of upcoming feature films, [[video game]] companies, and evening events such as The Masquerade; a costume contest, and other social receptions.
Typically there are over 175 hours of programming on all aspects of pop culture over the weekend.

{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2018}} {{about|the Spanish event|the band|San Fermin (band)}}
{{infobox| above = San Fermín| image = [[File:Chupinazo pamplona.jpg|250px]] | caption = Town Hall of Pamplona seconds after the initiation of the San Fermín festival with the chupinazo | label1 = name | data1 = San Fermín | label2 = Also called | data2 = Sanfermín, Sanfermines (plural) | label3 = Main location | data3 = [[Pamplona]], [[Spain]] | label6 = Begins | data6 = July 6; 12 p.m. (noon) | label7 = Ends | data7 = July 14; 12 a.m. (midnight) }}
The festival of '''San Fermín''' is a week-long, historically rooted celebration held annually in the city of [[Pamplona]], [[Navarra ]], [[Spain]]. The celebrations start at noon on the sixth of July, when the party starts with the setting off the pyrotechnic ''chupinazo'',{{efn|The ceremony, which dates to the beginning of the twentieth century, has been accompanied by ever-greater ceremony and is now televised all over the world. ([[:es:Chupinazo|Spanish Wikipedia:"Chupinazo"]]).}} and continue until midnight, on the fourteenth of July, with the singing of the ''Pobre de Mí''. While its most famous event is the encierro, or [[Running of the Bulls|the running of the bulls]], at 8:00 AM from July 7 to 14, the festival involves many other traditional and [[folklore|folkloric]] events. It is known locally as ''Sanfermines'' and is held in honor of [[Saint Fermin]], the co-patron of Navarre. Its events were central to the plot of ''[[The Sun Also Rises]]'', by [[Ernest Hemingway]], which brought it to the general attention of English-speaking people. It has become probably the most internationally renowned [[festival|fiesta]] in Spain. Over 1,000,000 people come to participate in this festival.
==History== ===Saint Fermín=== [[Fermin|Fermín]] is said to have been the son of a [[Ancient rome|Roman]] of [[Senate of the Roman Republic|senatorial]] rank in Pamplona in the 3rd century, who was converted to [[Christianity]] by [[Saint Honestus]], a disciple of [[Saturnin|Saint Saturninus]]. According to tradition, he was baptised by Saturninus (in Navarre also known as Saint Cernin) at the spot now known as the "Small Well of Saint Cernin"{{efn|In Spanish: ''Pocico de San Cernin''}}<ref name="Hist_Saint">{{cite web |url=http://www.turismo.navarra.es/eng/propuestas/san-fermines/desarrollo/santo.htm |title=History of... The saint-Saint San Fermin festival- Sanfermines-tourist information of Navarre |date= |publisher=Government of Navarre|accessdate=July 23, 2009}}</ref> Fermín was ordained a priest in Toulouse, and returned to Pamplona as its first bishop. On a later preaching voyage, Fermín was [[Decapitation|beheaded]] in [[Amiens]], France; and is now considered a [[martyr]] in the [[Catholic Church]].<ref name="Hist_Saint"/> It is believed he died on September 25, AD 303. There is no written record of veneration of the Saint in Pamplona until the 12th century. Saint Fermín, as well as Saint [[Francis Xavier]], are now the two [[Patron saint|patrons]] of Navarre.<ref name="Hist_Saint"/> In Pamplona, Saint Fermín is now sometimes said to have met his end by being dragged through the streets with angry bulls running after him, hence the tradition.
[[File:Escultura sanfermines.jpg|thumb|Statues dedicated to Sanfermines festival, in Pamplona]] The celebration of the festival has its origin in the combination of two different medieval events.<ref name="Hist_fiesta">{{cite web |url=http://www.turismo.navarra.es/eng/propuestas/san-fermines/desarrollo/fiesta.htm |title=History of... The fiesta of San Fermín Saint San Fermin festival- Sanfermines-tourist information on Navarre |date= |publisher=Government of Navarre|accessdate=July 29, 2009}}</ref> Commercial secular fairs were held at the beginning of the summer. As cattle merchants came into town with their animals, eventually [[bullfighting]] came to be organized as a part of the tradition.<ref name="Hist_fiesta"/> Specifically, they were first documented in the 14th century. On the other hand, religious ceremonies honoring the saint were held on October 10.<ref name="Hist_fiesta"/> However, in 1591 they were transferred to July 7 to take place at the same time as the fair, when Pamplona's weather is better.<ref name="Hist_fiesta"/> This is considered to be the beginning of the Sanfermines. During medieval times acts included an opening speech, musicians, tournaments, theatre, bullfights, dances or even fireworks.<ref name="Hist_fiesta"/> [[Running of the Bulls|Bullrunning]] appears in 17th and 18th century chronicles together with the presence of foreigners and the first concerns about the excessive drinking and dissolute behavior during the event.<ref name="Hist_fiesta"/> Finally, the Parade of Giants{{efn|In Spanish: ''Comparsa de Gigantes y Cabezudos''.}} was created in the mid-19th century.<ref name="Hist_fiesta"/> The first official [[bullring]] was constructed in 1844. ===Modern times=== [[File:Hemingway monument.jpg|thumb|Monument to Hemingway outside the bullring in Pamplona.]]
The worldwide fame of the modern festival, and the great number of foreign visitors it receives every year, are closely related to the description in [[Ernest Hemingway]]'s book [[The Sun Also Rises]]{{efn|Also known as ''Fiesta'', which in Spanish means ''party'' or ''carnival''}} and the reports he made as a journalist.<ref name="Hist_hemingway">{{cite web |url=http://www.turismo.navarra.es/eng/propuestas/san-fermines/desarrollo/hemingway.htm|title=History of... Ernest Hemingway-Saint San Fermin festival- Sanfermines-tourist information on Navarre |date= |publisher=Navarre tourist office|accessdate=July 29, 2009}}</ref> He was fascinated when he first visited in 1923, and returned many times until 1959.<ref name="Hist_hemingway"/> Hemingway was also deeply fond of bullrunnings and bullfights, but he did not participate in the running. Different city locations such as ''La Perla Hotel''<ref name="Hist_hemingway"/> or the ''Iruña Café'' are famous in part due to the fact that the writer used to visit them. Another famous American author, [[James A. Michener|James Michener]], wrote extensively about the festival and bullfighting in his non-fiction book ''[[Iberia (book)|Iberia]]''. His writing explained the art and business of bullfighting with tremendous 'gracia' by explaining the importance of 'pundonor'.
===Old times===
The San Fermín Festival of the past was not like it is today: it has changed gradually both for better and for worse. Originally most of the youth looked forward to the festivities all year, saving money until they had at least fifty pesetas, the minimum necessary to watch the running of the bulls, have a snack and wine, eat lunch and dinner out, and eat churros with brandy a couple of times each San Fermín day.{{what|date=July 2016}}
After the religious function, the group formed by the Authorities and village, they came back to the Home of “the town”, at about 90 minutes after leaving it. Then was effectuated the move, to contemplate the bulls that while they were waiting to move, they grazed in the grove.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mysanfermin.com/history/old-times/|title=Old Times|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=mysanfermin.com|access-date=}}</ref>{{what|date=July 2016}}
==Single day events==
===Chupinazo=== [[File:Chupinazo1.jpg|thumb|right|Chupinazo]] The opening of the festival is marked by setting off the pyrotechnic ''chupinazo'' (or ''txupinazo'' in [[Basque language]]). The rocket is launched at 12:00 noon on July 6 from a city hall balcony with thousands of people celebrating the act in the city hall square and other locations in Pamplona.<ref name="chupinazo">{{cite web|url=http://www.navarra.com/english/sanfermin/chupinazo.htm |title=The Sanfermines: the "chupinazo" |date= |publisher=navarra.com |accessdate=September 3, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090518054720/http://www.navarra.com/english/sanfermin/chupinazo.htm |archivedate=May 18, 2009 }}</ref> The chupinazo has officially marked the beginning of the fiesta since 1941. The person who sets it off is decided by the city mayor.<ref name="chupinazo2">{{cite web|url=http://www.sanfermin.com/index.php/en/historia/txupinazo/historia-del-txupinazo-hasta-1979|title=History of the txupinazo to 1980|date=|publisher=Kukuxumuxu S.L.|accessdate=July 10, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130712042851/http://www.sanfermin.com/index.php/en/historia/txupinazo/historia-del-txupinazo-hasta-1979|archivedate=July 12, 2013|df=}}</ref> Nevertheless, since 1979 tradition has been that each year after city elections the chupinazo is set off by a person from the different city council political groups beginning with the mayor and then political groups ordered by number of representatives.<ref name="chupinazo3">{{cite web|url=http://www.sanfermin.com/index.php/en/historia/txupinazo/historia-del-txupinazo-desde-1979|title=History of the txupinazo from 1979|date=|publisher=Kukuxumuxu S.L.|accessdate=July 10, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130712040913/http://www.sanfermin.com/index.php/en/historia/txupinazo/historia-del-txupinazo-desde-1979|archivedate=July 12, 2013|df=}}</ref> There have been exceptions to this tradition with some non-politicians being in charge of the act when they had performed significant achievements during the year. Examples of these exceptions were a player of the [[Osasuna|local soccer team]], or the president of the "giants and big-heads" group in its 150 years anniversary.<ref name="chupinazo4">{{cite web|url=http://www.sanfermin.com/index.php/en/historia/txupinazo/lanzadores-deportistas|title=A "Sporty" exception to the politicians|date=|publisher=Kukuxumuxu S.L.|accessdate=July 10, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130712040434/http://www.sanfermin.com/index.php/en/historia/txupinazo/lanzadores-deportistas|archivedate=July 12, 2013|df=}}</ref><ref name="chupinazo5">{{cite web|url=http://www.diariodenavarra.es/20100706/sanfermin/chupinazo-gigante.html?not=2010070601565999&idnot=2010070601565999&dia=20100706&seccion=sanfermin&seccion2=calle&chnl=50 |title=Entrevista a Jose Mari Ganuza |date=July 6, 2010 |author=A. Ollo |publisher=Diario de Navarra |accessdate=July 10, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140106143608/http://www.diariodenavarra.es/20100706/sanfermin/chupinazo-gigante.html?not=2010070601565999&idnot=2010070601565999&dia=20100706&seccion=sanfermin&seccion2=calle&chnl=50 |archivedate=January 6, 2014 }}</ref>
===Riau-Riau=== The ''Riau-Riau'' was a mass activity held on July 6. The members of the city council parade from the City Hall to a nearby chapel dedicated to Saint Fermín with participants dancing to the ''Astrain [[Waltz]]'' along the way.<ref name="ABC_history"/> The ritual was introduced in 1911 by [[Ignacio Baleztena Ascárate]].<ref name="ABC_history"/> The procession was removed from the festival calendar in 1992 for the sake of public order, as political activists used the "Riau-Riau" to promote clashes with authorities. Protesting youths would often block the way and it often took up to five hours for the city councilors to walk the 500 meters to the Saint Fermin chapel. Nevertheless, in recent years it has been held unofficially without the participation of the members of the city council. In 1996 and 2012 there were two failed attempts to restore the original act with the participation of the city council, both of them being cancelled due to the violent clashes with some participants.<ref name="riau-riau-2012">{{cite news |title= El Riau-Riau tendrá que esperar|author=Miren Imaz |url=http://www.diariovasco.com/v/20120707/al-dia-sociedad/riau-riau-tendra-esperar-20120707.html |newspaper=[[Diario Vasco]] |date=July 7, 2012 |accessdate=July 8, 2012}}</ref>
===Saint Fermin procession=== The key day of the festival is July 7, when thousands of people accompany the 15th-century statue of [[Saint Fermin]] through the old part of Pamplona. The statue is accompanied by dancers and street entertainers, and different political and religious authorities including the city mayor.<ref name="statue">{{cite web |url=http://www.turismo.navarra.es/eng/organice-viaje/recurso.aspx?o=3003 |title=Chapel of Saint Fermin-tourist information of Navarre |date= |publisher=Government of Navarre|accessdate=July 9, 2012}}</ref> During procession a [[Jota (music)|Jota]] (an ancient traditional dance) is performed for the saint, a rose is offered in the Saint Fernin well, and the "gigantes" (enormous wood-framed and papier-mâché puppet figures managed from inside) dance and twirl while the cathedral bell named María (Mary) peals.<ref name="procession">{{cite web|url=http://www.pamplona.es/verPagina.asp?idPag=28041PR&idioma=1|title=San Fermín 2012 – La Procesión|date=|publisher=Council of Pamplona|accessdate=July 9, 2012|language=Spanish|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120630051511/http://www.pamplona.es/VerPagina.asp?idPag=28041PR&idioma=1|archivedate=June 30, 2012|df=}}</ref>
===Struendo=== "El Struendo" ("The Roar"{{efn|In Spanish the correct spelling would be "Estruendo", however the name of the act is intentionally misspelled.}}) is a single day event with more than 50 years of tradition. It has been purposely left outside the official program and each year is celebrated on a different day, usually on a weekday so as to keep the crowds manageable. People gather at 11:59 pm at the Town Hall and make as much noise as possible for several hours mainly with drums but also bowls, whistles or any other objects.<ref name="ABC_history"/><ref name="riau riau">{{cite web|url=http://www.sanfermin.com/index.php/en/la-fiesta/otros-ritos/struendo-de-iruna/|title=The "Struendo"|date=|publisher=Kukuxumuxu S.L.|accessdate=July 10, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110710121037/http://www.sanfermin.com/index.php/en/la-fiesta/otros-ritos/struendo-de-iruna|archivedate=July 10, 2011|df=}}</ref>
===Pobre de mí=== After nine days of partying, the people of Pamplona meet in the City Hall Plaza at midnight on July 14, singing the traditional mournful notes of the ''Pobre de Mí'' ('Poor Me'), in a candlelit ending. The city mayor closes the festival with participants lighting a candle and removing their red handkerchief as the song is played by the local band, followed by a fireworks display at the city hall. This closing ceremony tradition started out in the 1920s.<ref name="ABC_history"/>
==Daily events==
===Running of the bulls=== [[File:Encierro 7 de julio de 2005.jpg|thumb|right|Running of the bulls]] The [[running of the bulls]] (In Spanish ''encierro or los toros de san Fermin''{{efn|from the verb encerrar, to lock/shut up}}) involves hundreds of people running in front of six bulls and another six steers down an 825-meter (0.51 mile) stretch of narrow streets of a section of the old town of Pamplona. The run ends in the [[Plaza de Toros de Pamplona|Pamplona's bullring]] taking a mean time of around 3 minutes where the bulls would be held until the afternoon's bullfight when they would be killed. Bullruns are held between July 7 and 14 and a different "encaste" (sub-breed) of bull appears each day.
The event begins at 8 a.m. when a first [[firecracker]] is lit to announce the release of the bulls from their corral. Before the year 1924 it started at 6 and at 7 between 1924 and 1974.<ref name="ABC_history">{{cite news| url=http://www.abc.es/20120709/local-navarra/abci-nacieron-sanfermines-201207091210.html| title=Así nacieron los sanfermines| author= M. Arrizabalaga | date=July 10, 2012 | newspaper=ABC| language=Spanish }}</ref> Runners gather earlier at the beginning of the itinerary to ask for the protection of the Saint by singing a chant three times before a small statue of San Fermín which has been placed in a raised niche in a wall: “''To San Fermin we ask to be our patron saint and to guide us in '''the running of the bulls''', giving to us his blessing''”.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mysanfermin.com/bulls/running-of-the-bulls/|title=Running of the Bulls - MySanFermin.com|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> A second cracker signals that the last bull has left the corral. There are six fighting bulls accompanied by six [[ox]]en (often white and brown colored) that guide them to the "plaza" and followed by three more not fighting oxen. There are also some shepherds guiding the bulls, wearing green T-shirts and holding long poles. Once all of the bulls have entered the arena, a third rocket is released while a fourth firecracker indicates that the bulls are in their bullpens and the run has concluded. After the end of the run young cows with wrapped horns{{efn|In Spanish: ''Vaquillas enboladas''.}} are released in the bullring and toss the participants, to the amusement of the crowd.
The circuit has only changed slightly since 1852 as the former bullring was located close to the present one. Before that date the bullrunning ended in the "castle plaza", still not far from the present bullring.<ref name="ABC_history"/> While the origin of this tradition was the necessity to move the bulls from outside the city to the bullring for the bullfight it is not clear when citizens began to run in front of them. There are written records in 1787 that the tradition was already well established with no memory of its beginning.<ref name="ABC_history"/> The tradition of singing for protection to the saint dates back to 1962.<ref name="ABC_history"/>
The event is dangerous. Since 1925, 15<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/explainer/2007/07/i_was_gored_by_a_bull.html |title=I Was Gored by a Bull. Is my life in danger? |author=Michelle Tsai |date=July 12, 2007 |newspaper=Slate Magazine |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130731101753/http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/explainer/2007/07/i_was_gored_by_a_bull.html |archivedate=July 31, 2013 }}</ref> people have been killed during the event –– most recently on July 10, 2009<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/jul/10/running-bulls-kill-man-pamplona| title=Bull kills man at Pamplona festival | newspaper=The Guardian | date=July 10, 2009 | author=Giles Tremlett }}</ref>—and every year between 200 and 300 people are injured during the run although most injuries are [[contusion]]s due to falls and are not serious.<ref name="Ayuntamiento">{{cite web| title= The Bull Run| url= http://www.pamplona.net/VerPagina.asp?IdPag=287&Idioma=5| publisher= Ayuntamiento de Pamplona (Council of Pamplona)| date= | accessdate= July 21, 2008| deadurl= yes| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080529011527/http://www.pamplona.net/VerPagina.asp?IdPag=287&Idioma=5| archivedate= May 29, 2008| df= }}</ref>
===Giants and big-heads parade=== [[File:Comparsa pamplona jorge urdanoz.jpg|thumb|right|Pamplona's Giants and Big-heads parade family photo. From back to front and left to right we can see the American, Asian, African and European pairs of giants (last row), the six ''kilikis'' and the 5 big-heads (second row), the ''zaldikos'', and members of the parade who carry the figures (front row).]] Every day, during the morning, there is a parade of ''[[gigantes y cabezudos]]'' (English: "giants and big-heads", respectively), with the giant figures being more than 150 years old. The eight giant figures were built by Tadeo Amorena, a painter from Pamplona, in 1860, and represent four pairs of kings and queens of four different races and places (Europe, Asia, America and Africa). Their height is around {{convert|4|meters|feet}} each, and they are carried by a dancer inside a wooden structure. During the parade, giants dance following the rhythm of traditional music. The remaining 17 figures include 6 ''kilikis'', 5 big-heads, and 6 ''zaldikos'', built at different times between 1860 and 1941. ''Kilikis'' and big-heads are caricaturesque, but human-like figures that are carried as helmets. Big-heads masks are up to {{convert|1|meters|feet}} tall, and ''kilikis'' slightly smaller. While big-heads simply precede the giants and wave their hands at spectators, ''kilikis'' run after children, hitting them with a [[foam]] truncheon. ''Zaldikos'', figures representing horses with their riders, also run after children with a truncheon.<ref>{{cite book |title=Historias del viejo Pamplona |author=Juan José Martirena Ruíz|year=2001 |publisher=Ayuntamiento de Pamplona |location=Pamplona |isbn=84-89590-90-7}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Gigantes de Navarra |author=Unai Lako, Aitor Calleja |year= 2010|publisher=EGN |location=Pamplona |isbn=978-84-937633-1-2}}</ref>
===Traditional sports=== There are exhibitions and competitions of [[Basque rural sports]] every morning in the "Plaza de los Fueros", a square close to the city citadel, although they were formerly held in the bullring.<ref name="rural">{{cite web |url=http://www.sanfermines.net/ingles/que_hacer_y_ver.php|title=Rural Sports|date= |work=Sanfermines.net|publisher=Asociación de empresarios de hostelería de Navarra (Businessmen association of hotel and bar's industry of Navarre)|accessdate=September 26, 2010}}</ref> Sports include [[Harrijasotzaileak|stone lifting]], [[Aizkolaritza|wood cutting]], or [[hay bale]] lifting.<ref name="rural"/> On the other hand, the [[Jai alai]] tournament of Sanfermin is a prestigious competition of this variety of [[basque pelota]]. It is held in one of the [[Fronton (court)|courts]] of the city.<ref name="rural"/> Betting is common during these events.<ref name="rural"/>
===Bullfight=== Every afternoon from July 7 to 14 there is a [[bullfight]] in which the 6 bulls that have been driven to the bullring during the bullrunning of that day are killed. It begins at 6pm.<ref name="The corrida">{{cite web |url=http://www.turismo.navarra.es/eng/propuestas/san-fermines/desarrollo/corrida.htm|title=The bulls... The corrida-San Fermin|date= |publisher=Oficina de turismo de Navarra (Navarre tourist office)|accessdate=August 25, 2010}}</ref> In addition the 5th bullfight with younger bulls and not fully trained bullfighters is performed while the 6th features bullfighters on horses (in Spanish "rejoneo"). While the bullring of the city is the fourth largest in size{{Clarification|is this attendance capacity or area|date=June 2018}} in the world, it is full every afternoon and tickets are hard to find.<ref name="The corrida"/>
===Fireworks=== Every night at 23:00, a [[firework]] spectacle is held at the [[citadel]] park. Fireworks spectacles have been known to occur in Sanfermin as far back as 1595. Since the year 2000 an international fireworks contest is held.<ref name="fireworks">{{cite web |url=http://www.sanfermines.net/ingles/fuegos.php|title=Fireworks|date= |work=Sanfermines.net|publisher=Asociación de empresarios de hostelería de Navarra (Businessmen association of hotel and bar's industry of Navarre)|accessdate=September 26, 2010}}</ref> Thousands of people watch them seated on the grass around the citadel.<ref name="fireworks"/>

{{convert|2.5|x|3|m|ft|abbr=on}} | power = 1100 watts | launch_date = 2020 | launch_rocket = [[Atlas V]] 411{{cite news | title = NASA Selects United Launch Alliance Atlas V Rocket to Launch Solar instrument_type = | telescope_name = | telescope_type = [[Ritchey–Chrétien]] [[reflecting telescope|reflector]] | telescope_diameter = {{convert|160|mm|in|abbr=on}} | telescope_focal_length= {{convert|2.5|m|ft|abbr=on}} | telescope_area = | telescope_wavelength = [[visible light]], [[ultraviolet]], [[X-rays]] | telescope_resolution = | instruments_list = {{Infobox spaceflight/Instruments | acronym1 = EPD | name1 = Energetic Particle Detector | acronym2 = EUI | name2 = Extreme Ultraviolet Imager | acronym3 = MAG | name3 = Magnetometer | acronym4 = METIS | name4 = Coronagraph | acronym5 = PHI | name5 = Polarimetric and Helioseismic Imager | acronym6 = RPW | name6 = Radio and Plasma Waves | acronym7 = SoloHI | name7 = Heliospheric Imager | acronym8 = SPICE | name8 = Spectral Imaging of the Coronal Environment | acronym9 = STIX | name9 = X-ray Spectrometer/Telescope | acronym10 = SWPA | name10 = Solar Wind Plasma Analyser }} | insignia = File:Solar Orbiter insignia.png | insignia_caption = ESA solar system insignia for ''Solar Orbiter'' | insignia_alt = | insignia_size = 180x180px | programme = '''[[Cosmic Vision]]''' | previous_mission = ''[[CHEOPS]]'' | next_mission = ''[[Euclid (spacecraft)|Euclid]]'' }} '''Solar Orbiter''' ('''SolO''') is a planned [[Sun]]-observing [[satellite]], under development by the [[European Space Agency]] (ESA). The mission will be launched with an [[Atlas V]] from the [[Cape Canaveral AFS]] in [[Florida]] in 2020. SolO is intended to perform detailed measurements of the inner [[heliosphere]] and nascent [[solar wind]], and perform close observations of the polar regions of the Sun, which is difficult to do from [[Earth]], both serving to answer the question 'How does the Sun create and control the heliosphere?' The Solar Orbiter will make observations of the Sun from an eccentric orbit moving as close as ~60 [[solar radius|solar radii (RS)]], or 0.284 [[astronomical unit]]s (AU), placing it inside [[Mercury (planet)|Mercury]]'s perihelion of 0.3075 AU.{{cite web|url=http://www.kis.uni-freiburg.de/index.php?id=58&L=1|title=Kiepenheuer-Institut fuer Sonnenphysik: SolarOrbiter PHI-ISS|website=Kis.uni-freiburg.de|accessdate=9 August 2018}} During the planned 7 year mission the orbital inclination will be raised to about 25°. [[File:Suncomparison.svg|thumb|right|A comparison of the size of the [[Sun]] as seen from [[Earth]] (left, 1 AU) and from the Solar Orbiter spacecraft (0.284 AU,right)]] [[File:Solar Orbiter Structural Thermal Model.jpg|thumb|This photo shows the Solar Orbiter structural thermal model shortly before leaving the [[Airbus Defence and Space]] facility in Stevenage, UK.]] ==Scientific objectives== The spacecraft will make a close approach to the [[Sun]] every five months. The closest approach will be positioned to allow a repeated study of the same region of the solar atmosphere.{{cn|date=May 2018}} Solar Orbiter will be able to watch magnetic activity building up in the atmosphere that can lead to powerful [[solar flare]]s or eruptions. Researchers will also have the chance to co-ordinate observations with NASA's ''[[Parker Solar Probe]]'' mission (2018 - 2025) which will make in situ measurements in the Sun's extended [[corona]]. The objective of the mission is to perform close-up, high-resolution studies of the Sun and its inner [[heliosphere]]. The new understanding will help answer these questions: * How and where do the [[solar wind]] plasma and [[Sun#Magnetic field|magnetic field]] originate in the [[corona]]? * How do solar transients drive heliospheric variability? * How do solar eruptions produce [[Solar energetic particles|energetic particle]] radiation that fills the heliosphere? * How does the [[solar dynamo]] work and drive connections between the Sun and the heliosphere? ==Payload== The science payload is composed of: {{cite web |url=http://www.esa.int/Our_Activities/Space_Science/Solar_Orbiter |title=Solar Orbiter |publisher=[[European Space Agency]] |access-date=2 August 2018}} ;Heliospheric in-situ instruments: * Solar Wind Analyser (SWA): To measure [[solar wind]] properties and composition{{cite web|url=http://www.ucl.ac.uk/mssl/space-plasma-physics/missions/solar-orbiter|title=Solar Orbiter|website=Ucl.ac.uk|accessdate=9 August 2018}} * Energetic Particle Detector (EPD): To measure suprathermal ions, electrons, neutral atoms, as well as energetic particles in the energy range from few keV/nuc to relativistic electrons and ions up to 100 [[electronvolt|MeV]] (protons) and 200 MeV/nuc (heavy ions){{cite web|url=http://www.physik.uni-kiel.de/de/institute/ieap/ag-wimmer/solo|title=Solar Orbiter's Energetic Particle Detector (EPD)|accessdate=7 September 2018}} * Magnetometer (MAG): will provide detailed measurements of the magnetic field{{cite web|url=http://www3.imperial.ac.uk/spat/research/missions/space_missions/solar_orbiter|title=Space and Atmospheric Physics|website=Imperial College London|accessdate=9 August 2018}} * Radio and Plasma Wave analyser (RPW): To measure magnetic and electric fields at high time resolution{{cite web|url=http://lesia.obspm.fr/Solar-Orbiter.html|title=La mission Solar Orbiter - LESIA - Observatoire de Paris|website=Lesia.obspm.fr|accessdate=9 August 2018}} ;Solar remote-sensing instruments: * Polarimetric and Helioseismic Imager (PHI): To provide high-resolution and full-disk measurements of the photospheric magnetic field{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120516083026/http://www.mps.mpg.de/en/projekte/solar-orbiter/phi/|title=MPS: PHI: Polarimetric and Helioseismic Imager|date=16 May 2012|website=Web.archive.org|accessdate=9 August 2018}} * EUV full-Sun and high-resolution Imager (EUI): To image various layers of the solar atmosphere * EUV spectral Imager (SPICE): To provide spectral imaging of solar disk and corona, characterise plasma properties at the Sun{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110511231002/http://www.mps.mpg.de/en/projekte/solar-orbiter/spice/|title=MPS: SPICE: Spectral Imaging of the Coronal Environment|date=11 May 2011|website=Web.archive.org|accessdate=9 August 2018}} * [[Spectrometer Telescope for Imaging X-rays]] (STIX): To provide imaging spectroscopy of thermal and non-thermal solar X-ray emission from 4 to 150 keV * Coronagraph (Metis): To provide simultaneous UV (121.6 nm), and polarised visible light imaging of the corona{{cite web|url=http://metis.oato.inaf.it|title=Metis Solar Orbiter|website=Metis.oato.inaf.it|accessdate=9 August 2018}} * Heliospheric Imager (SoloHI): To image quasi-steady and transient flows of the solar wind (US provided){{cite web|url=http://www.nrl.navy.mil/ssd/branches/7630/SoloHI|title=Solar Orbiter Heliospheric Imager (SoloHI) - Space Science Division|website=Nrl.navy.mil|accessdate=9 August 2018}} == Timeline and status == * 2012 April : €300M contract to build orbiter awarded to Astrium UK.{{cite web |url=http://sci.esa.int/solar-orbiter/50295-esa-contracts-astrium-uk-to-build-solar-orbiter/ |title=ESA contracts Astrium UK to build Solar Orbiter|website=Sci.esa.int |date=April 2012 }} * 2014 June : Solar shield completes 2 week bake test.{{cite web |url=http://www.esa.int/Our_Activities/Space_Engineering_Technology/Solar_Orbiter_s_shield_takes_Sun_s_heat |title=Solar Orbiter's shield takes Sun's heat |website=Esa.int|date=June 2014}} *2018 September: Spacecraft is shipped to [[IABG]] in Germany to begin the environmental test campaign{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-45553019|title=Solar Orbiter: Spacecraft to leave UK bound for the Sun|last=|first=|date=|website=BBC|archive-url=|archive-date=18 September 2018|dead-url=|access-date=}}. === Launch delays === In April 2015 the launch was set back from July 2017 to October 2018.http://sci.esa.int/solar-orbiter/55772-solar-orbiter-launch-moved-to-2018/ In August 2017 Solar Orbiter was considered "on track" to be launched in February 2019.{{cite web |url=http://www.aircosmosinternational.com/europe-s-solar-orbiter-on-track-for-2019-launch-99097 |title=Europe's Solar Orbiter on track for 2019 launch |work=[[Air & Cosmos]] |date=28 August 2017 |accessdate=19 September 2017}} {{As of|August 2018}} the launch is "foreseen for 2020". === Trajectory === After launch, the Orbiter will take approximately 3.5 years, using repeated gravity assists from Earth and Venus, to reach its operational orbit, an elliptical orbit with perihelion 0.28 AU and aphelion 0.9 AU. Over the expected mission duration of 7 years, it will use additional gravity assists from Venus to raise its inclination from 0° to 25°, allowing it a better view of the Sun's poles. If an extended mission is approved, the inclination could rise further to 34°.{{cite web |url=http://sci.esa.int/solar-orbiter/44181-mission-operations/ |title=ESA Science & Technology: Mission Operations |website=Sci.esa.int |date=13 April 2015 | access-date=20 March 2018}}{{cite web |url=http://sci.esa.int/solar-orbiter/51168-summary/ |title=ESA Science & Technology: Summar|website=Sci.esa.inty |date=28 February 2018 | access-date=20 March 2018}} == See also == * [[Advanced Composition Explorer]] (ACE), launched 1997, still operational * [[French space program]] * ''[[Parker Solar Probe]]'', launched in August 2018 * [[Solar Sentinels]], proposed 2006 and 2008 * [[Space sunshade]] * [[STEREO]] (Solar Terrestrial Relations Observatory), launched 2006, still operational * [[WIND (spacecraft)|WIND]], launched 1994, still operational * [[Ulysses (spacecraft)|Ulysses]], launched 1990 ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} * [http://sci.esa.int/solarorbiter Solar Orbiter homepage] * [https://directory.eoportal.org/web/eoportal/satellite-missions/s/solar-orbiter-mission Solar Orbiter at eoPortal] {{Sun spacecraft}} {{ESA projects}} {{Future spaceflights}} [[Category:Missions to the Sun]] [[Category:European Space Agency space probes]] [[Category:Solar space observatories]] [[Category:Proposed space probes]] [[Category:Solar telescopes]] [[Category:2020 in spaceflight]] [[Category:Living With a Star Program]] [[Category:Cosmic Vision]]

34 merchant vessels sunk | campaignbox = {{Campaignbox Axis-Soviet War}} {{Campaignbox Barbarossa}} {{Campaignbox Leningrad and Baltics 1941-1944}} }} The '''Soviet evacuation of Tallinn''', also called '''Tallinn disaster''' or '''Russian [[Dunkirk evacuation|Dunkirk]]''', was a Soviet operation to evacuate the 190 ships of the [[Baltic Fleet]], units of the [[Red Army]], and pro-Soviet civilians from the fleet's encircled main base of [[Tallinn]] in [[Soviet occupation of the Baltic states (1940)|Soviet-occupied]] [[Estonia]] during August 1941.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6MglnqQn7_8C&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|author=Harrison E. Salisbury|year=2003|title=The 900 Days: The siege of Leningrad|publisher=Da Capo Press|location=Cambridge, Massachusetts|chapter=Tallinn disaster; Russian Dunkirk|pages=221–242}} Soviet forces had occupied Estonia in June 1940. After the [[Operation Barbarossa|German invasion of the Soviet Union]] began on 22 June 1941, German forces advanced rapidly through the [[Soviet occupation of Baltic states|Soviet-occupied Baltic states]], and by the end of August the [[Estonian Soviet Socialist Republic|Estonian]] capital of Tallinn was surrounded by German forces, while a large part of the Red Banner Baltic Fleet was bottled up in Tallinn harbour. In expectation of a Soviet breakout, the [[Kriegsmarine]] and the [[Finnish Navy]] had started on 8 August 1941 to lay [[naval mines|minefields]] off Cape [[Juminda]] on the [[Lahemaa]] coast. While Soviet minesweepers tried to clear a path for convoys through the minefields, German coastal artillery installed a battery of {{convert|150|mm|abbr=on}} guns near Cape Juminda and the Finnish navy gathered their 2nd [[Motor Torpedo Boat]] Flotilla with [[VMV class patrol boat|patrol boats]] VMV9, VMV10, VMV11 and VMV17. At the same time the German 3. Schnellbootflottille with [[E-boat]]s S-26, S-27, S-39, S-40 and S-101 was concentrated at [[Suomenlinna]] outside [[Helsinki]]. German [[Junkers Ju 88]] bombers from Kampfgruppe 806 based on airfields in Estonia were put on alert. On 19 August the final German assault on Tallinn began. During the night of 27/28 August 1941 the Soviet [[10th Rifle Corps (Soviet)|10th Rifle Corps]] disengaged from the enemy and boarded transports in Tallinn. The embarkation was protected by smoke screens, however, the mine-sweeping in the days before the evacuation began was ineffective due to bad weather, and there were no Soviet aircraft available for protecting the embarkation. This, together with heavy German shelling and aerial bombardment killed at least 1,000 of the evacuees in the harbor. ==Gauntlet in the Gulf of Finland== [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 141-0154, Reval, Hafen.jpg|right|thumb|225px|The Port of Tallinn on 1 September 1941 after having been seized by Germans]] Twenty large transports, eight auxiliary ships, nine small transports, a tanker, a tug, and a tender were organized into four convoys, protected by the [[Soviet cruiser Kirov|Soviet cruiser ''Kirov'']], with Admiral [[Vladimir Tributs]] on board, two flotilla leaders, nine destroyers, three torpedo boats, twelve submarines, ten modern and fifteen obsolete minehunters, 22 minesweepers, 21 submarine chasers, three gun boats, a minelayer, thirteen patrol vessels and eleven torpedo boats.{{cite book|editor-last=Rohwer|editor-first=J.|title=Seemacht. Eine Seekriegsgeschichte von der Antike bis zur Gegenwart|trans-title=Sea Power. A Naval History|chapter=Der Krieg in der Ostsee|trans-chapter=The War at Sea in the Baltics|last1=Potter|first1=Elmar P.|last2=Nimitz|first2=Chester W.|publisher=Manfred Pawlak Verlagsgesellschaft mbH|location=Herrsching|year=1986|pages=602–622|ISBN=3-88199-082-8}} On 28 August [[KG 77]] and KGr 806 sank the 2,026 grt steamer ''Vironia'', the 2,317 grt ''Lucerne'', the 1,423 grt ''Atis Kronvalds'' and the 2,250 grt ice breaker ''Krisjanis Valdemars''. The rest of the Soviet fleet were forced to change course. This took them through a heavily mined area. As a result, 21 Soviet warships, including five destroyers, struck mines and sank. On 29 August, the Luftwaffe, now reinforced with [[KG 76]], [[KG 4]] and [[KG 1]], accounted for the transport ships ''Vtoraya Pyatiletka'' (3,974 grt), ''Kalpaks'' (2,190 grt) and ''Leningradsovet'' (1,270 grt) sunk. In addition, the ships ''Ivan Papanin'', ''Saule'', ''Kazakhstan'' and the ''Serp i Molot'' were damaged by I./[[KG 4]], which also sank three more. Some 5,000 Soviet soldiers died.Bergström 2007a, p. 60. Later that evening the armada was attacked by Finnish and German torpedo boats, and the chaotic situation made organized mine sweeping impossible. Darkness fell at 22:00 and the Soviet armada stopped and anchored at midnight in the heavily mined water. Early on 29 August Ju 88 bombers attacked the remains of the convoys off [[Suursaari]], sinking two transports. Meanwhile, the undamaged ships made best speed to reach the safety of the [[Kronstadt]] batteries. The heavily damaged merchant ship ''Kazakhstan'' disembarked 2300 men of the 5000 on board before steaming on to Kronstadt. In the following days ships operating from Suursaari rescued 12,160 survivors. The Soviet evacuation of Tallinn succeeded in evacuating 165 ships, 28,000 passengers and 66,000 tons of equipment.[http://users.tkk.fi/~jaromaa/Navygallery/Background/Wartime/Tallinn-evac.htm Finnish navy in Continuation War, year 1941] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080920155139/http://users.tkk.fi/~jaromaa/Navygallery/Background/Wartime/Tallinn-evac.htm |date=2008-09-20 }}[http://www.feldgrau.com/baltsea.html Naval War in the Baltic Sea 1941-1945] At least 12,400 are thought to have drowned[http://www.hs.fi/english/article/Juminda+2881941+To+the+memory+of+the+drowned+-+all+12000+of+them/1135259946924 "Juminda, 28.8.1941: To the memory of the drowned - all 12,000 of them" Helsingen Sanomat 5 September 2010] in circumstances little known outside the former Soviet Union. The event was long downplayed by the Communist regime after the war. The evacuation may have been the bloodiest naval disaster since the [[battle of Lepanto]].{{citation needed|date=April 2014}} On the sixtieth anniversary a memorial was unveiled at Juminda.[http://vp1992-2001.president.ee/eng/PrinditavDokument.asp?ID=9135 Press Service of the Office of the President; Kadriorg, August 24, 2001] ==Partial list of sunk ships== [[File:Juminda monument 1.jpg|thumb|Juminda monument.]] [[File:II maailmasõjas hukkunute ühishaud-"Eesti rand".JPG|thumb|Graves of men lost on ''[[Eestirand]]'' on [[Prangli]] Island where it was beached.]] *Latvian Icebreaker ''Krišjānis Valdemārs'' *Soviet Submarine ''[[Soviet S class submarine|S 5]]'' - 28 August 1941, Gulf of Finland{{cite book|last= Krivosheev|first= G.F.|title = Soviet Casualties and Combat Losses in the Twentieth Century|publisher=Greenhill Books|location=London|year=1997|ISBN=1-85367-280-7|pages=265–271}} *Soviet Submarine ''[[Soviet S class submarine|S 6]]'' *Soviet Submarine ''[[Shchuka class submarine|Shch 301]]'' - 28 August 1941, off Cape Juminda *Soviet Destroyer [[Soviet destroyer Yakov Sverdlov|''Yakov Sverdlov'']] - 28 August 1941, off Mohni island *Soviet Destroyer ''[[Izyaslav class destroyer|Kalinin]]'' - 28 August 1941, off Cape Juminda *Soviet Destroyer ''[[Orfey class destroyer|Artem]]'' - 28 August 1941, off Cape Juminda *Soviet Destroyer ''[[Orfey class destroyer|Volodarski]]'' - 28 August 1941, off Cape Juminda *Soviet Destroyer ''[[Soobrazitelny class destroyer|Skoryi]]'' - 28 August 1941, off Cape Juminda *Patrol vessel ''[[Uragan class guard ship|Sneg]]'' - 28 August 1941, off Cape Juminda *Patrol vessel ''[[Uragan class guard ship|Tsiklon]]''- 28 August 1941, off Cape Juminda *Patrol vessel ''Jupiter''D.A. Bertke, D. Kindell, G. Smith, "WORLD WAR II SEA WAR VOLUME 4 GERMANY SENDS RUSSIA TO THE ALLIES. Day-to-Day Naval Actions from June 1941 through November 1941", p. 177 *Gunboat ''I-8'' - 28 August 1941, off Cape Juminda *Gunboat ''Amgun'' *Minesweeper No. 71 (''Crab'') - 28 August 1941, off Cape Juminda *Minesweeper No. 42 (''Lenvodput-13'') - 28 August 1941, off Cape Juminda *Minesweeper [[Fugas-class minesweeper#Ships|T-214 (''Bugel'')]], off Cape Juminda *Minesweeper [[Fugas-class minesweeper#Ships|T-216]], off Cape Juminda *Minelayer TTS-56 (''Barometr'') *Minelayer TTS-71 (''Krab'') *Minelayer TTS-42 (''Izhorets-17'') *Netlayer ''Vyatka'' *Netlayer ''Onega'' *Guard (rescue) ship ''Saturn'' *Submarine chaser ''MO 202'' *Motor torpedo boat ''TK 103'' *25 large and 9 smaller merchantmen (most of them lost to mines), including: **Estonian transport ''[[Eestirand|SS Eestirand]] (VT 532)'' - 24 August 1941, off Prangli Island **VT -511/ALEV (1446grt) **VT-512/TOBOL (2758grt) **VT-547/JARVAMAA (1363grt) **EVERITA (3251grt) **VT-518/LUGA (2329grt) **VT-512/KUMARI (237grt) **BALKHASH (2191grt) **JANA (2917grt) **VT -584/NAISSAAR (1839grt) **VT -537/ERGONAUTIS (206grt) **VT -530/ELLA (1522grt) **AUSMA (1791grt) **Tanker TN-12 (1700grt). Also, mines heavily damaged [[Leningrad-class destroyer#Ships|destroyer Minsk]], destroyers [[Gnevny-class destroyer#Baltic Fleet|Gordy]] and [[Soobrazitelnyy-class destroyer#Baltic Fleet|Slavnyi]] , [[Fugas-class minesweeper#Ships|minesweeper T-205]] and other ships. ==See also== *[[List of shipwrecks in August 1941]] ==References== {{Reflist}} * Bergstrom, Christer (2007a). {{Infobox company | name = The Antarctic Sun | logo = | type = | industry = News | fate = | predecessor = <!-- or: | predecessors = --> | successor = <!-- or: | successors = --> | founded = October 27, 1996 | founder = <!-- or: | founders = --> | defunct = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | hq_location_city = | hq_location_country = | area_served = [[Antarctica]] | key_people = | products = Newspaper | owner = <!-- or: | owners = --> | num_employees = 15 | num_employees_year = <!-- Year of num_employees data (if known) --> | parent = | website = https://antarcticsun.usap.gov/ }} '''''The Antarctic Sun''''' is an online [[newspaper]] with "News about the [[United States Antarctic Program|USAP]], the Ice, and the People." It is funded by the National Science Foundation (contract no. NSFDACS1219442) by its prime civilian contractor, [[Lockheed Martin]] Antarctic Support Contract.<ref Name="AboutTheSun">{{cite web |quote= ''The Antarctic Sun'' is produced by ASC for the U.S. Antarctic Program (USAP). |title= About The Antarctic Sun |publisher= U. S. Antarctic Program |url= http://antarcticsun.usap.gov/aboutTheSun/ |accessdate= March 4, 2015 }}</ref>
The online publication has been covering cutting edge science for the [[National Science Foundation]] since 1997–1998 [[austral summer]], though it can trace its history back to the 1950s when the U.S. Navy ran logistics for the USAP.<ref Name="tenyears">{{cite web |first= Peter |last= Rejcek |title= Ten Years and Counting |work= The Antarctic Sun |date= November 1, 2007 |url= http://antarcticsun.usap.gov/features/contentHandler.cfm?id=1262 |accessdate= November 11, 2007 }}</ref> From the austral summer of 1997-98 to 2006-07, ''The Antarctic Sun'' was produced at [[McMurdo Station]] between the months of October and February. Since October 2007, it has been a year-round news website managed out of the Denver, Colorado area.<ref Name="tenyears">{{cite web |first= Peter |last= Rejcek |title= Ten Years and Counting |work= The Antarctic Sun |date= November 1, 2007 |url= http://antarcticsun.usap.gov/features/contentHandler.cfm?id=1262 |accessdate= November 11, 2007 }}</ref>
The website covers both science and features. The former includes biology, glaciology, geology, astrophysics and oceanography, among others. Features include USAP operations, Antarctic history, and profiles on people.
==Antarctic Sun Journalists== In order of tenure, from most recent: *Mike Lucibella *Peter Rejcek *Steven Profaizer *Steve Martaindale *Emily Stone *Brien Barnett *Kris Kuenning *Melanie Conner *Mark Sabbatini *Kristan Hutchison *Beth Minneci *Jeff Inglis *Josh Landis *Aaron Spitzer *Ginny Figlar *Alexander Colhoun

{{italic title}} {{for|''The Best of Friends'', 1902 play with Lionel Barrymore, viewed as pro-Boer by London critics|Cecil Raleigh}} '''''The Best of Friends''''' is an epistolary play by [[Hugh Whitemore]] about the friendship of [[George Bernard Shaw]], [[Sydney Cockerell]], and Dame [[Laurentia McLachlan]], based in the lengthy correspondence that passed between them for over 25 years. It was inspired by ''[[The Nun, the Infidel, and the Superman]]'' by Dame [[Felicitas Corrigan]], a [[Benedictine]] nun at [[Stanbrook Abbey]] in the U.K.
George Bernard Shaw is considered one of the most important English-language playwrights of the 20th century. Sydney Cockerell was the curator of the [[Fitzwilliam Museum]] and was well-connected to many intellectuals of his time. Dame Laurentia was a [[Benedictine]] nun and [[Abbess]] of Stanbrook from 1931-1953 and an authority on church music.
Originally produced as a stage play it first ran at the [[Apollo Theatre]] in 1988, with [[Ray McAnally]] as Shaw, Sir [[John Gielgud]] as Cockerell, and [[Rosemary Harris]] as McLachlan.
In 1991 it was filmed for television, under the direction by Alvin Rakoff, with [[Patrick McGoohan]] as Shaw, Sir [[John Gielgud]], and Dame [[Wendy Hiller]].
The play was performed in New York in 1993 with [[Roy Dotrice]] as Shaw, [[Michael Allinson]] and [[Diana Douglas]], and was revived in 2006 at the Hampstead Theatre, London, with [[Roy Dotrice]], [[Michael Pennington]] and [[Patricia Routledge]].
==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{imdb title | id=0109245| title=The Best of Friends}} * [http://www.musicomh.com/theatre/best-of-friends_0306.htm OMH 2006 Review]

The '''Dam Short Film Festival''' is a film festival held annually in [[Boulder City, Nevada]], typically in early February. [[Lee Lanier]] and Anita Lanier are the original co-founders of the festival. The festival is organized by the Dam Short Film Society, a non-profit 501(c)3 Nevada corporation. Past festival sponsors have included [[The Art Institutes]], the [[Nevada Film Office]], the [[Hacienda Hotel and Casino]], and [[Cirque du Soleil]]. The Society receives annual grants from the [[National Endowment for the Arts]] via the Nevada Arts Council.<ref>http://nac.nevadaculture.org/index.php?option=com_content&id=1892:nevada-arts-council-awards-more-than-a-half-million-dollars-to-state-arts-communities-</ref>
Started in 2005, the Dam Short Film Festival only screens films that run between 1 and 40 minutes. Generally, there are between 100 and 140 short films programmed each year. Although most of the festival shorts are submitted by student, independent, and other "up-and-coming" filmmakers, the stiff competition means many of the shorts have been produced involving film professionals. These have included [[Academy Award|Oscar]]-winner [[Louis Gossett Jr.]] in "Window," [[Academy Award|Oscar]]-winner, [[Tom Hanks]], [[William Shatner]], and [[Michael York (actor)|Michael York]] in "Why Shakespeare?", the late [[Bela Lugosi]] narrating an animation based on the [[Edgar Allan Poe]] classic "[[The Tell-Tale Heart]]", [[Francesco Quinn]] in "[[The Gnostic]]", and [[Robert Wagner]] and [[Lori Singer]] in "[[Little Victim]] "{{citation needed|date=January 2016}} The short films are arranged into thematic programs, such as international drama, crime drama, dramedy, science-fiction, horror, comedy, avant-garde, underground, and animation. In addition to the regular screenings, the festival presents special showcases and retrospectives; for example, the 2009 event featured a showcase dedicated to documentary filmmaker Jay Rosenblatt while 2008 included a program dedicated to animator [[Jim Blashfield]]<ref>http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2009/feb/05/have-dam-good-time/</ref><ref>http://www.lasvegassun.com/blogs/culture/2008/jan/21/dam-short-filmfest-announces-lineup/</ref> The festival also presents parties, mixers, filmmaker panels, and Q&A sessions with attending filmmakers.
In 2008, the Festival moved to the historic 400-seat Boulder Theatre. The Theatre was built in 1931 and is currently owned by [[Desi Arnaz Jr.]] and his wife Amy.<ref>http://www.bouldertheatre.com/</ref> 2014 marked the 10th anniversary of the festival.<ref>http://www.lasvegasweekly.com/ae/film/2014/feb/06/decade-dam-short-film-festival/</ref> At present, [[Lee Lanier]] serves as the Dam Short Film Society's executive director while John LaBonney serves as festival director. The Society has a working board of directors that varies from 4 to 6 members.<ref>http://www.damshortfilm.org/about/</ref>

[http://www.lasvegassun.com/sunbin/stories/do/2007/feb/08/566617638.html "Take Five: Dam Short Film Festival"], ''Las Vegas Sun'', February 8, 2007. *Brown, Joe. [http://www.lasvegassun.com/blogs/culture/2008/jan/21/dam-short-filmfest-announces-lineup/ "Dam Short Filmfest announces lineup"], ''Las Vegas Sun'', January 21, 2008. *Patterson, Carol. {{other uses2|Photographer}} {{Infobox opera | name = The Photographer | composer = [[Philip Glass]] | image = Philip Glass 018.jpg | image_upright = | caption = The composer in 1993 | "mixed media performance accompanied by music" | librettist = | based_on = life of [[Eadweard Muybridge]] | premiere_date = {{Start date|1982}} | premiere_location = [[Holland Festival]], Amsterdam }} '''''The Photographer''''' is a three-part mixed media performance accompanied by music (also sometimes referred to as a [[chamber opera]]) by [[composer]] [[Philip Glass]]. The libretto is based on the life and [[homicide]] trial of 19th-century English [[photographer]] [[Eadweard Muybridge]]. Commissioned by the [[Holland Festival]], the opera was first performed in 1982 at the [[Royal Palace (Amsterdam)|Royal Palace]] in [[Amsterdam]].
==Subject== Eadweard Muybridge was an English-born photographer who relocated to the American West and was an early pioneer in photographic technology. He photographed well-known landscapes of [[Yosemite]] that pushed the aesthetic and technological boundaries of the medium. His early photographic motion studies conducted in association with [[Leland Stanford]] led to the earliest moving photographic images.
In 1874, Muybridge murdered Major Harry Larkyns (referred to as 'Colonel Harry Larkyns' in this work), whom he suspected of being his wife's lover, and was acquitted by a jury against the instructions of the judge on the ground of justifiable homicide. His trial is well-known because his defense argued that a head injury incurred in a stagecoach accident altered his personality, which modern neuroscientists believe could have been caused by certain types of brain damage.
The text included in Glass' work is based on words drawn from the transcripts of the trial and Muybridge's actual letters to his wife. The second act features a slideshow of Muybridge's photographs. While based on historical events in Muybridge's life, the work also comments on aspects of Muybridge's work, melding both themes.
==Synopsis== The form of this work consists of three acts: a play with incidental music, a concert accompanying a slideshow of Muybridge's work, and a dance with musical accompaniment. In total, the piece lasts about 90 minutes.
===Act I=== Act I is a play that includes three incidental pieces of music that fit into the play. The play recounts Muybridge's murder of Major Harry Larkyns and the trial, with an irreverent tone.
The incidental piece "A Gentleman's Honor", includes words drawn from the actual trial transcript, commentary, and Muybridge's letters. It draws on the incident in which Flora sent Larkyns a portrait of Muybridge's son Florado, seeming to imply that Larkyns could be the father ('Whose baby is this'), and draws on the commentary of spectators ('All that white hair and a long white beard'), as well as referencing Muybridge's carriage accident and his later motion studies ('Horses in the air '). The phrases 'Artificial moonlight' and 'Artificial sky' may refer to techniques used by Muybridge in his landscape technology (overlaying clouds onto his images). Glass notes that he originally conceived the text of A Gentleman's Honor as based on a poem by Muybridge called "Circles", but Glass reconsidered and asked [[David Byrne]] to use material from the trial itself, as well as Muybridge's letters. <ref>{{cite interview |last=Glass |first=Philip |subject-link=Philip Glass|interviewer=Jennings |title=Philip Glass Interviewed by Russ Jennings (April 18, 1983) |url=https://archive.org/details/PhillipGlassWithJennings |location=San Francisco |date=April 18, 1983 |access-date=December 28, 2014}}</ref>
===Act II=== Act II is a violin solo, or "concert", that either features a figure representing Muybridge in the darkroom in the background or a slideshow of images by Muybridge. Critics have compared the see-saw sounds of the solo violin to a hoe-down or "early American" sound, although Glass claims this analogy was not necessarily intentional.<ref>{{cite interview |last=Glass |first=Philip |subject-link=Philip Glass|interviewer=Jennings |title=Philip Glass Interviewed by Russ Jennings (April 18, 1983) |url=https://archive.org/details/PhillipGlassWithJennings |location=San Francisco |date=April 18, 1983 |access-date=December 28, 2014}}</ref>
===Act III=== In Act III, the characters from Act I return for a dance (including Muybridge, Flora, Larkyns, and Victorian bystanders). In some productions, the dance features photographs "developed" in the second half.
==Composition and premieres== The preview of this work premiered in May 1982 at the Royal Palace in Amsterdam for Queen Beatrix and Prince Claus of the Netherlands and commissioned by the Holland Festival, and its first public performance was in June 1982 as part of the Holland Festival, for which the work was commissioned. The work was suggested and developed by the Dutch director/designer Rob Malasch. Later, Glass rewrote the piece and renamed it "The Photographer: Far from the Truth". Though based on Malasch's original premise, this new version of the play was rewritten by Rob Coe. Glass also performed this work as a selection of incidental songs from Act I and the instrumental work in Act III. <ref>{{cite news |first=John |last=Rockwell |coauthors= |title=PHILIP GLASS'S 'PHOTOGRAPHER' |work=New York Times |page= |date=October 7, 1983 |accessdate=28 December 2014 |quote= |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/07/arts/philip-glass-s-photographer.html}}</ref>
Glass's distinctive minimalist musical style complements the theme of the opera, since the ideas of repetitive sounds and small changes seem to mirror Muybridge's techniques in his famous motion studies.<ref>{{cite web |title= Muybridge: the man who made pictures move |url=https://www.npr.org/2010/04/13/125899013/muybridge-the-man-who-made-pictures-move |publisher= National Public Radio |accessdate=December 28, 2014| date=April 13, 2010 |last=Ulaby |first=Neda |authorlink=Neda Ulaby}}</ref> Despite Muybridge's achievements and this relationship to the composer's work, the work does not necessarily treat the subject of Muybridge's trial reverently, and the dance appears to use the subject as an opportunity to comment on the contradictory mores of Muybridge's own time.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Tobias |first=Tobi |date=October 24, 1883 |title=Home Truths |quote="David Gordon's expert movement is the best part of The Photographer." |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=l-ICAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA115&lpg=PA115&dq=rob+coe+the+photographer+muybridge+play&source=bl&ots=9_QEpyoUjZ&sig=kneZCWJJoVIfyIEkZJOnOzEPrBQ&hl=en&sa=X&ei=f3SgVMXVBNfWoAT0iYHwBg&ved=0CCkQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=rob%20coe%20the%20photographer%20muybridge%20play&f=false |journal=The New York Times Magazine |location= |publisher= |accessdate=December 28, 2014 }}</ref> Glass has stated that he intended to reflect the idea of a "Victorian melodrama" in his music. <ref>{{cite interview |last=Glass |first=Philip |subject-link=Philip Glass|interviewer=Jennings |title=Philip Glass Interviewed by Russ Jennings (April 18, 1983) |url=https://archive.org/details/PhillipGlassWithJennings |location=San Francisco |date=April 18, 1983 |access-date=December 28, 2014}}</ref>
This piece seems to show Glass's transitioning from ensemble works like Einstein on the Beach to more traditional instrumentation in his later works. Glass has stated that using the word "minimalist" to apply to this work is "misleading" and would not reflect what the listener would expect to hear. <ref>{{cite interview |last=Glass |first=Philip |subject-link=Philip Glass|interviewer=Jennings |title=Philip Glass Interviewed by Russ Jennings (April 18, 1983) |url=https://archive.org/details/PhillipGlassWithJennings |location=San Francisco |date=April 18, 1983 |access-date=December 28, 2014}}</ref>
==Recording== The recording was conceived with the idea that most listeners would not have experienced the stage work. Several pieces were shortened or left off the album entirely, and the order of the music is changed. Only two of the original three incidental pieces contained in Act I are included.<ref>{{cite interview |last=Glass |first=Philip |subject-link=Philip Glass|interviewer=Jennings |title=Philip Glass Interviewed by Russ Jennings (April 18, 1983) |url=https://archive.org/details/PhillipGlassWithJennings |location=San Francisco |date=April 18, 1983 |access-date=December 28, 2014}}</ref>
The album was released on June 26, 1984 by CBS Records / Epic and is just 42 minutes long (compared to the 90-minute-long original work).<ref>{{cite web |access-date=December 28, 2014 |url=http://www.philipglass.com/music/recordings/photographer.php |title=The photographer |date=2014}}</ref>
==Roles== *[[Edweard Muybridge]] *Flora Shallcross Stone Muybridge *Colonel Harry Larkyns (based on Major Harry Larkyns) *Observers in Victorian costume
==Instrumentation== :[[Woodwinds]]: [[flute]], [[soprano saxophone]], [[alto saxophone]], [[baritone saxophone]] :[[Brass]]: 2 [[French horn]]s, 2 [[trumpets]], 2 [[trombone]]s :[[Percussion]]: [[Piano]], bass [[synthesizer]], [[electronic organ]] :[[Vocals]]: [[Choir|Chorus]] :[[String instrument|Strings]]: solo [[violin]], [[String instrument|Strings]]
